\DeclareDocumentCommand \inferrule { s O {} m m}{%
  \IfBooleanTF{#1}%
  {%
    \mpr@inferstar[#2]{#3}{#4}%
  }{%
    \mpr@inferrule[#2]{#3}{#4}%
  }%
  \IfValueT{#2}%
  {%
    \my@name@inferrule{#2}%
  }%
}
\NewDocumentCommand \my@name@inferrule { m }{%
  \def\@currentlabelname{\textsc{#1}}%
}

% support for hat, overline, underline, vec, and sim combining charactors
\protected\def\afteracc{\directlua{
    local nest = tex.nest[tex.nest.ptr]
    local last = nest.tail
    if not (last and last.id == 18) then
      error'I can only put accents on simple noads.'
    end
    if last.sub or last.sup then
      error'If you want accents on a superscript or subscript, please use braces.'
    end
    local acc = node.new(21, 1)
    acc.nucleus = last.nucleus
    last.nucleus = nil
    local is_bottom = token.scan_keyword'bot' and 'bot_accent' or 'accent'
    acc[is_bottom] = node.new(23)
    acc[is_bottom].fam, acc[is_bottom].char = 0, token.scan_int()
    nest.head = node.insert_after(node.remove(nest.head, last), nil, acc)
    nest.tail = acc
    node.flush_node(last)
  }}
\AtBeginDocument{
\begingroup
  \def\UnicodeMathSymbol#1#2#3#4{%
    \ifx#3\mathaccent
      \def\mytmpmacro{\afteracc#1 }%
      \global\letcharcode#1=\mytmpmacro
      \global\mathcode#1="8000
    \else\ifx#3\mathbotaccentwide
      \def\mytmpmacro{\afteracc bot#1 }%
      \global\letcharcode#1=\mytmpmacro
      \global\mathcode#1="8000
    \fi\fi
  }
  \input{unicode-math-table}
\endgroup
}

\section{GKAT with Output}

Symbolic GKAT with Output (SyGO) automata extends GKAT automata, where instead of only emitting accepts, it allows to produce a finite set of outputs \(O\).
In the case of GKAT and Guarded NetKAT, the output set \(O\) is a singleton set \(\acc{}\); whereas in CF-GKAT, the outcome can be any continuations.

Formally, a SyGO Automata is defined over a set of tests \(\BExp\), a set of outputs \(O\), and a set of state \(S\);  
with a start state \(sÃÇ ‚àà S\), and two functions:
\begin{align*}
  œµ & : S ‚Üí ùí´(\BExp √ó O) & 
  Œ¥ & : S ‚Üí ùí´(\BExp √ó S √ó Œ£).
\end{align*}
Intuitively, \(œµ(s, o)\) returns the condition required to immediately return the output \(o\) when at the state \(s\); and if \((b, s') ‚àà Œ¥(s)\) then it means that from state \(s\), when condition \(b\) is met, the machine will transition to \(s'\).

To ensure the determinism of SyGO automata, we will impose a \emph{disjointness condition}, i.e. all the conditions starting from \(s\) will be disjoint.
Formally, fix any \(s ‚àà S\):
\begin{itemize}
  \item if \((b‚ÇÅ, o‚ÇÅ) ‚àà œµ(s)\) and \((b‚ÇÇ, o‚ÇÇ) ‚àà œµ(s)\), then \(o‚ÇÅ ‚â† o‚ÇÇ\) implies \(b‚ÇÅ\) is disjoint with \(b‚ÇÇ\);
  \item if \((b‚ÇÅ, s‚ÇÅ, p) ‚àà Œ¥(s)\) and \((b‚ÇÇ, s‚ÇÇ, q) ‚àà Œ¥(s)\), then \(s‚ÇÅ ‚â† s‚ÇÇ\) or \(p ‚â† q\) implies \(b‚ÇÅ\) is disjoint with \(b‚ÇÇ\);
  \item for all \(œµ(s, o)\) is disjoint with all \(b\) s.t. there exists \(s'\) where \((b, s') ‚àà Œ¥(s)\).
\end{itemize}

We list our bisimulation algorithm in~\Cref{alg:symb-bisim}.

\begin{algorithm*}
  \caption{Symbolic On-the-fly Bisimulation Algorithm}\label{alg:symb-bisim}
  \begin{algorithmic}
      \Function{equiv}{$s ‚àà S, u ‚àà U$}
      \If {\Call{eq}{$s, u$}} {\Return true}
      \ElsIf {\Call{knownDead\(_S\)}{$s$}} {\Return \Call{isDead\(_U\)}{$u$}} 
      \ElsIf {\Call{knownDead\(_U\)}{$u$}} {\Return \Call{isDead\(_S\)}{$s$}} 
      \Else {}
      \Return {
          %\Comment{conditions of ~\Cref{thm:symb-recursive-construction}}
          \\\vspace{5px}
          \(\qquad
          \begin{aligned}
              & ‚àÄ o ‚àà O, œµ(s, o) ‚â° ‚ãÅ œµ(u, o) \mathrel{\&\!\&} \\  
              & s \transvia{b ‚à£ p} s' \text{ and } (b ‚àß œÅ_U(u)) ‚â¢ 0 \text{ implies \Call{isDead$_S$}{$s'$}} \mathrel{\&\!\&}\\
              & u \transvia{b ‚à£ p} u' \text{ and } (œÅ_S(s) ‚àß b) ‚â¢ 0 \text{ implies \Call{isDead$_U$}{$u'$}} \mathrel{\&\!\&}\\
              & s \transvia{b ‚à£ p} s' \text{ and } u \transvia{c ‚à£ p} u' \text{ implies } \text{\Call{Union}{$s$, $u$}}; \text{\Call{Equiv}{$s', u'$}} \mathrel{\&\!\&}\\
              & s \transvia{b ‚à£ p} s' \text{ and } u \transvia{c ‚à£ q} u' \text{ and } p ‚â† q \text{ implies \Call{isDead}{$s'$} and \Call{isDead}{$u'$}}
          \end{aligned}\)
      }
      \EndIf
      \EndFunction
  \end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm*}


\section{Guarded NetKAT}

Guarded NetKAT~\cite{wasserstein_GUARDEDNETKATSOUNDNESS_2023} is a variant of NetKAT that disallows non-deterministic assignments. 
For Guarded NetKAT, the possible outputs \(O\) are \emph{partial assignments} \(œÉ: X ‚Üõ V\), which are partial functions that encodes all the \emph{known} variable assignment at this stage of the execution.
And we can extend \(œÉ: X ‚Üõ V\):
\[œÉ[x ‚Ü¶ v](y) ‚âú \begin{cases}
  v & \text{if } x = y \\  
  œÉ(x) & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}\]

Here is the syntax for Guarded NetKAT over a set of values \(V\) and variable \(X\):
\begin{align*}
  \BExp ‚àã b, c & ‚âú 
    \false 
    ‚à£ \true 
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} x = v~(x ‚àà X, v ‚àà V)} 
    ‚à£ b ‚àß c 
    ‚à£ b ‚à® c 
    ‚à£ ¬¨ b 
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} b[œÉ]}\\
  \Exp ‚àã e, f & ‚âú 
    b ‚àà \BExp
    ‚à£ p ‚àà \{\comDup\}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue}x := v~(x ‚àà X, v ‚àà V)}
    ‚à£ e +_b f 
    ‚à£ e; f 
    ‚à£ e^{(b)}
\end{align*}
Note that we added a boolean expression \(b[œÉ]\), but following the syntax of original Guarded NetKAT~\cite{wasserstein_GUARDEDNETKATSOUNDNESS_2023}, we disallow this construct from NetKAT programs. 
\(b[œÉ]\) generates a new predicate by plugging in the value of \(œÉ: X ‚Üõ V\) into the boolean expression \(b\).
Formally \(b[œÉ]\) is defined inductively as follows:
\begin{align*}
  \false[œÉ] & ‚âú \false & 
  \true[œÉ] & ‚âú \true \\
  (x = i)[œÉ] & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    x = i & x ‚àâ \dom{œÉ} \\
    \true & œÉ(x) = i \\  
    \false & œÉ(x) ‚â† i 
  \end{cases} & 
  (b ‚àß c)[œÉ] & ‚âú b[œÉ] ‚àß c[œÉ] \\
  (b ‚à® c)[œÉ] & ‚âú b[œÉ] ‚à® c[œÉ] &
  (¬¨ b)[œÉ] & ‚âú ¬¨ (b[œÉ])
\end{align*}

The state in the symbolic Guarded NetKAT automata has two components: \(œÉ: X ‚Üõ V\) indicating the current known assignment to variables, and \(e: \Exp\) representing the rest of the expression
\begin{mathpar}
  \inferrule
  {\\}
  {(œÉ, \comAssert{b})\transOut{b[œÉ]}{œÉ}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {\\}
  {(œÉ, x := v)\transOut{\true}{œÉ[x ‚Ü¶ v]}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {\\}
  {(œÉ,\comDup)\transvia{b_œÉ ‚à£ \comDup} (œÉ,\comSkip)}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, e) \transOut{c}{œÉ'}}
  {(œÉ, e +_b f) \transOut{b[œÉ] ‚àß c}{œÉ'}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, f) \transOut{c}{œÉ'}}
  {(œÉ, e +_b f) \transOut{¬¨b[œÉ] ‚àß c}{œÉ'}}
  \and
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, e) \transvia{c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e')}
  {(œÉ, e +_b f) \transvia{b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e')}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, f) \transvia{c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', f')}
  {(œÉ, e +_b f) \transvia{b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', f')}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e) \transOut{b}{œÉ‚ÇÇ} \\ (œÉ‚ÇÇ, f) \transOut{c}{œÉ‚ÇÉ}}
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e; f) \transOut{b ‚àß c}{œÉ‚ÇÉ}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e) \transOut{b}{œÉ‚ÇÇ} \\ (œÉ‚ÇÇ, f) \transvia{b ‚à£ p} (œÉ‚ÇÉ, f')}
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e; f) \transvia{b ‚àß c ‚à£ p} (œÉ‚ÇÉ, f')}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, e) \transvia{b ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e')}
  {(œÉ, e;f) \transvia{b ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e';f)}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {\\}
  {(œÉ, e^{(b)}) \transOut{¬¨b[œÉ]}{œÉ}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e) \transOut{c}{œÉ‚ÇÇ} \\  (œÉ‚ÇÇ, e^{(b)}) \transOut{a}{œÉ‚ÇÉ}}
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e^{(b)}) \transOut{b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚àß a}{œÉ‚ÇÉ}}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e) \transOut{c}{œÉ‚ÇÇ} \\  (œÉ‚ÇÇ, e^{(b)}) \transvia{a ‚à£ p} (œÉ‚ÇÉ, f)}
  {(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e^{(b)}) \transvia{b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚àß a ‚à£ p} (œÉ‚ÇÉ, f)}
  \and  
  \inferrule
  {(œÉ, e) \transvia{c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e')}
  {(œÉ, e^{(b)}) \transvia{b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚à£ p} (œÉ', e'; e^{(b)})}
\end{mathpar}
Notice that when \((œÉ‚ÇÅ, e) \transOut{c}{œÉ‚ÇÇ}\), the derivative rule with the source \((œÉ‚ÇÅ, e^{(b)})\) appears to be self-referential. 
However, since there are only finitely many partial assignments \(œÉ: X ‚Üõ V\), for any finite set \(X\) and \(V\); there are only finitely many cases to check.
Practically, we use the following recursive algorithm to compute \(œµ(œÉ, e^{(b)})\), where \(Œ®\) denotes the set of all explored \(œÉ\).
\begin{align*}
  œµÃÇ(œÉ, e^{(b)}, Œ®) & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    ‚àÖ & \text{if } œÉ ‚àà Œ® \\  
    \begin{aligned}
      & \{(¬¨b[œÉ], œÉ)\} ‚à™ \\
      & \{(b[œÉ] ‚àß c ‚àß a, œÉ‚ÇÇ) ‚à£ (a, œÉ‚ÇÇ) ‚àà œµÃÇ(œÉ‚ÇÅ, e^{(b)}, Œ® ‚à™ \{œÉ\})\}
    \end{aligned}
     & \text{else, if } (œÉ, e)\transOut{c}{œÉ‚ÇÅ}\\
  \end{cases}\\
  œµ(œÉ, e^{(b)}) & ‚âú œµÃÇ(œÉ, e^{(b)}, ‚àÖ)
\end{align*}


\section{Control-Flow GKAT}

\subsection{Syntax}

Control-Flow GKAT (or CF-GKAT)~\cite{zhang_CFGKATEfficientValidation_2025} extends Guarded Kleene Algebra with tests with common control-flow operators, including indicator variable, break, continue, and goto's. 

Similar to GKAT, the syntax of CF-GKAT is also two sorted, we highlight the newly added :
\begin{align*}
  \BExp ‚àã b, c ‚âú{}&
  \false
  ‚à£ \true
  ‚à£ t  ‚àà  T
  ‚à£ {\color{blue}x = i\ (i ‚àà I)}
  ‚à£ b  \lor  c
  ‚à£ b  \land  c
  ‚à£ ¬¨ b \\
  \Exp ‚àã e, f ‚âú{}&
    \comAssert{b}
    ‚à£ p  ‚àà  Œ£
    ‚à£ {\color{blue}x := i\ (i ‚àà I)}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue}e ‚ãÜ f}
    ‚à£ e; f
    ‚à£ e +_b f
    ‚à£ \\
  &
    e^{(b)}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} \comBrk}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} \comCont}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} \comRet}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} \comGoto{l}\ (l ‚àà  L)}
    ‚à£ {\color{blue} \comLabel{l}\ (l ‚àà L)}
\end{align*}
Additionally, for a CF-GKAT expression \(e\) to be a CF-GKAT \emph{program} (or \emph{well-formed expressions}), we enforce the following conditions:
\begin{itemize}
  \item If \(\comLabel{l}\) does not occur in \(e\), then so is \(\comGoto{l}\).
  \item Each \(\comLabel{l}\) only appear once in the program \(e\).
  \item No \(\comBrk\) or \(\comRet\) outside a while-loop.  
  \item All programs need to end with a return, i.e. \(e\) need to be of the form \(f; \comRet\) where \(f ‚àà \Exp\).
  \item The \(‚ãÜ\) operator cannot appear in the program. 
\end{itemize}
In addition to the syntax introduced in the original paper~\cite{zhang_CFGKATEfficientValidation_2025}, we added two additional constructions: \(\comCont\), a common control-flow manipulating structure; and the \emph{unfolding star} \(e ‚ãÜ f\) is an expression that is generated from loop unfolding, hence cannot appear in any CF-GKAT programs.
We use the common shorthand \(\comSkip\) for \(\comAssert{\true}\). On the other hand, \(\comAssert{\false}\) is the divergent or constant rejection program; in fact, it is equivalent to \(\comSkip^{(\true)}\).

\subsection{Label Extraction}

First, we define the label extraction process, where we extract the meaning of each label syntactically: given a label \(l ‚àà L\), \((-)_l\) will take an input program, and give the expression that corresponds to the meaning of \(l\) in the input program:
\begin{align*}
  (-)_{l}&: \Prog ‚Üí \Exp \\  
  (\comLabel{l'})_{l} & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    \comSkip & l = l' \\  
    \comAssert{\false} & l ‚â† l'
  \end{cases} & 
  (e +_b f)_{l} & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    (e)_{l} & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(e\)}\\
    (f)_{l} & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(f\)}
  \end{cases} \\  
  (e; f)_{l} & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    (e)_{l}; f & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(e\)}\\
    (f)_{l} & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(f\)}
  \end{cases} & 
  (e ‚ãÜ f)_{l} & ‚âú \begin{cases}
    (e)_{l} ‚ãÜ f & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(e\)}\\
    (f)_{l} & \text{if \(\comLabel{l}\) occurs in \(f\)}
  \end{cases} \\
  (e^{(b)})_{l} & ‚âú 
    (e)_l ‚ãÜ e^{(b)}
\end{align*}
And the label extraction \((e)_l\) for every the other program \(e\) is defined to be \(\comAssert{\false}\).
Notice the \(‚ãÜ\) operation is produced in the loop case, this serves as an example of loop unfolding.

For a boolean expression \(b ‚àà \BExp\), the semantics is

The symbolic derivatives of CF-GKAT can be defined as follows:
